context_meta.summary: Several times a week, Lou Stepanek drives to the Hiawatha Care Center in Iowa to spend time with someone who hasn’t seemed to recognize him for more than a decade: his wife. text: My mother-in-law was a school teacher for 43 years. She taught Special Ed. It takes a special human being to do that. She went into the Drop program and worked an additional 4 years in the school system, but not in Special Ed too much. At 69 she had to retire, and at age 70 the symptoms started. About a year later the family decided it was best to put her in an assisted living home. The family had to transfer all her assets to her children. She received $3,400 a month in retirement which the Assisted Living Home took to take care of her. We were fortunate in that the home was just a quarter mile from my house and my wife is a registered nurse who was very close to her mom. She visited her everyday, sometimes twice in a day if she was off from work. This was good in many ways, including the fact that the home knew she was close by and could pop in any time. Over a 3 year period I watched my mother-in-law deteriorate, and I watched my wife in pain dealing with it, and all I could do was hug her and tell her I much I loved her. There were 6 other brothers and sisters and only one of the brothers really visited her often. I told my wife how she could hold her head up high and know in her heart that she took care of her mom. One day during her last year of life I went with my wife to visit her. She wasn't talking much then, but out of no where she looks at my wife from her bed and tells her with tears rolling down her face. "You are a really good daughter. I had to leave the room because the tears were flowing, and because I knew that she knew her time on this earth was coming to an end. My wife was  with her when she passed at the young age of 74. I will always remember her as one of the best human beings I was lucky enough to have in my life. I just wish I would have told her so.

context_meta.summary: After President Donald Trump’s election and a corresponding spike in anti-Muslim hate crimes, one small group in the Kansas City area started organizing monthly “Meet a Muslim” events ― an effort to show community members who Muslims really are in real life, as opposed to the negative stereotypesthey might seein the news. The events were an idea from the nonprofit Crescent Peace Society, which has been seeking to raise awareness and improve understanding of Muslim cultures through interfaith events and dialogue since its founding in 1996. The volunteer-run group was started by a handful of Muslim parents after the Oklahoma City bombing, when some of their kids were afraid to return to school because classmates said they were responsible for the attack.

context_meta.summary: In August 2014, shortly after police officer Darren Wilson shot and killed an unarmed black man named Michael Brown, members of the St. Louis, Missouri, community took to the streets to protest police brutality and racial injustice in America. Three years later, in the same month, white supremacists and neo-Nazis marched on the streets of Charlottesville, Virginia, to protest the removal of a monument to Confederate general Robert E. Lee. Photos of Black Lives Matter demonstrators alongside police in riot gear, as well as images of grieving UVA students juxtaposed with white supremacists bearing tiki torches, flooded social media.
